summary: This is a U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) approval notice for an H1B work visa petition filed by Jeffrey Epstein for Ghislaine Maxwell. The document approves Maxwell's petition to work for Epstein, valid from November 5, 1992, to November 4, 1995, with the visa to be issued at the U.S. consulate in London.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Filed the I-129 Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker to sponsor Ghislaine Maxwell's H1B visa. Listed as the Chairman at 457 Madison Ave, New York, NY.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The beneficiary of the approved H1B work visa petition filed by Jeffrey Epstein. Her visa is approved for employment by Epstein from 1992 to 1995.

connections.description: Epstein is the petitioner sponsoring Maxwell's H1B work visa, establishing a formal employer-employee relationship as recognized by U.S. immigration authorities.

events.title: H1B Visa Petition Approval
events.description: The U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service approves Jeffrey Epstein's I-129 petition for Ghislaine Maxwell to obtain an H1B work visa.

locations: 457 Madison Ave 4th Fl, New York, NY 10022 (Jeffrey Epstein's business address)
Saint Albans, VT 05479-0001 (INS Eastern Service Center address)
London (U.S. Consulate designated for visa issuance)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein formally sponsored Ghislaine Maxwell for an H1B work visa in 1992, establishing a legal employer-employee relationship.
The visa was approved for a three-year period from November 5, 1992, to November 4, 1995.
The document lists Epstein's business address as 457 Madison Avenue in New York City.
Maxwell's visa was to be processed through the U.S. consulate in London, indicating she was likely abroad at the time of approval.
The approval notice explicitly states that visa approval itself does not authorize employment; authorization occurs upon admission to the U.S. in the proper classification.
